bibl.title: Letter from John Whelden to Philip Showalter Hench, September 5, 1951

div1.p: Bellevue Medical Center, at New York University, plans to celebrate the centenary of Reed's birth. Since Hench is unable to attend, Wheldon requests that Hench send a message to be read during the ceremony.

div1.head: Letter from John Whelden to Philip Showalter Hench, September 5, 1951

Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Next Thursday, September 13th, as you undoubtedly know, is the
100th Anniversary of the birth of Walter Reed.

As he is an alumnus of New York University College of Medicine,
Class of '97, Dean Currier McEwen and our Alumni Association are
holding an informal tea with appropriate ceremonies and also
opening an exhibit concerning Dr. Reed's life and work, both
events in honor of this anniversary, on that date. A portrait
of Dr. Reed, drawn by Dr. Frank Netter of our alumni, will be
presented to the College.

We realize, of course, that lack of time and the distance that
separates us will prevent your attending these ceremonies, but
in view of your interest in Dr. Reed, we wish to extend a cordial
invitation to you to be present. I know that Dean McEwen would
want to send this invitation himself but, unfortunately, he is
out of town and will not return for several days.

Lacking your presence at the ceremonies, we think it would be
appropriate to have a message from you to be read to the assembled
guests and made available to newspapermen. If you would like to
have this done, please address a telegram, collect, to Dean Currier
McEwen, New York University College of Medicine, 477 First Avenue,
New York, to be delivered on September 13th.

I hope that this idea will please you and that you will be able to
participate in this event honoring Dr. Reed.
